examples.description: 1. What is the syntax for staging a change in index.html if it is in the root dir?
examples.full_description: GIT 1. What is the syntax for staging a change in index.html if it is in the root dir?

examples.description: 2. What is the syntax for staging all files, including new, modified, and deleted files?
examples.full_description: GIT 2. What is the syntax for staging all files, including new, modified, and deleted files?

examples.description:
3. What is the syntax for committing all staged changes with the message
      'update link styles'?
examples.full_description:
GIT 3. What is the syntax for committing all staged changes with the message
      'update link styles'?

examples.description:
4. What command allows you to add all previously all tracked, modified files
      and create a message, 'add img to index' for the commit in one command?
examples.full_description:
GIT 4. What command allows you to add all previously all tracked, modified files
      and create a message, 'add img to index' for the commit in one command?

examples.description:
5. From the master branch, what is the syntax for pushing the master branch
      to the remote master branch where the remote is called 'origin'?
examples.full_description:
GIT 5. From the master branch, what is the syntax for pushing the master branch
      to the remote master branch where the remote is called 'origin'?

examples.description:
6. From the feature branch 'add-links', what is the syntax for creating a
      remote add-links branch with all of the local branch's content?
      (remote is still called 'origin')
examples.full_description:
GIT 6. From the feature branch 'add-links', what is the syntax for creating a
      remote add-links branch with all of the local branch's content?
      (remote is still called 'origin')

examples.description:
7. From the master branch, what is the syntax for pushing the master branch to the
      # remote master branch where the remote is called 'upstream'?
examples.full_description:
GIT 7. From the master branch, what is the syntax for pushing the master branch to the
      # remote master branch where the remote is called 'upstream'?

examples.description:
8. From the feature branch 'add-image', what is the syntax for creating a remote
      add-image branch with all of the local branch's content?
      (remote is still called 'upstream')
examples.full_description:
GIT 8. From the feature branch 'add-image', what is the syntax for creating a remote
      add-image branch with all of the local branch's content?
      (remote is still called 'upstream')

examples.description: 9. What command do you run to update all branches from all remotes?
examples.full_description: GIT 9. What command do you run to update all branches from all remotes?

examples.description:
10. Locally you have a master branch, remotely there is a master & add-nav-bar branch.
      You run 'git fetch --all'.
      What command would you need to run to view and change 'add-nav-bar' branch locally?
examples.full_description:
GIT 10. Locally you have a master branch, remotely there is a master & add-nav-bar branch.
      You run 'git fetch --all'.
      What command would you need to run to view and change 'add-nav-bar' branch locally?

examples.description:
11. What command do you run to update the local master branch with the
      master branch on the remote 'upstream'?
examples.full_description:
GIT 11. What command do you run to update the local master branch with the
      master branch on the remote 'upstream'?

examples.description: 12. Is 'git pull' the same as running 'git fetch' followed by 'git merge'?
examples.full_description: GIT 12. Is 'git pull' the same as running 'git fetch' followed by 'git merge'?

examples.description:
13. From the add-img branch, what command do you run to fetch and merge all the
      changes from the add-img branch on the remote 'origin'?
examples.full_description:
GIT 13. From the add-img branch, what command do you run to fetch and merge all the
      changes from the add-img branch on the remote 'origin'?

      from the add-img branch on the remote 'upstream'?

examples.description:
19. 'git branch style-image' followed by 'git checkout style-image'

examples.description: 20. It is best practice to add a feature on the master branch

examples.description:
21. If you're working on a project on master and you create a new branch,
      that branch will be empty until you add code
examples.full_description:
GIT 21. If you're working on a project on master and you create a new branch,

examples.description:
22. The branch that you are 'on' does not affect the content of a branch
      that you create: for instance, a branch made off of master will look exactly
      like a branch made off of `add-walrus-and-polar-bear`
examples.full_description:
GIT 22. The branch that you are 'on' does not affect the content of a branch
      that you create: for instance, a branch made off of master will look exactly
      like a branch made off of `add-walrus-and-polar-bear`

examples.description: 23. To merge a feature branch into master, you must first be on master

examples.description:
30. If index.html is being tracked and you modify it, but don't stage this change,
      what color will it be if you run 'git status'?

GIT 30. If index.html is being tracked and you modify it, but don't stage this change,
      what color will it be if you run 'git status'?

31. If index.html is being tracked and you modify and stage the change,
      what color will it be if you run 'git status'?
examples.full_description:
GIT 31. If index.html is being tracked and you modify and stage the change,

examples.description:
32. If you clone down a repo and make one change that you add and commit locally,
     assuming no one has pushed to your remote since you cloned it, will 'git status' say
     you're ahead or behind origin/master?
examples.full_description:
GIT 32. If you clone down a repo and make one change that you add and commit locally,
     assuming no one has pushed to your remote since you cloned it, will 'git status' say
     you're ahead or behind origin/master?

examples.description:
33. If you clone down a repo at noon and don't touch it but three minues later,
      someone else pushes two commits to it, will 'git status' say you are ahead or
      behind when you run it at 12:05pm
examples.full_description:
GIT 33. If you clone down a repo at noon and don't touch it but three minues later,
      someone else pushes two commits to it, will 'git status' say you are ahead or
      behind when you run it at 12:05pm

examples.description:
34. If you clone down a repo and make one change that you add and commit locally,
     and one developer has pushed to your remote since you cloned it,
     will 'git status' say you're ahead or behind (or both) origin/master?
examples.full_description:
GIT 34. If you clone down a repo and make one change that you add and commit locally,
     and one developer has pushed to your remote since you cloned it,
     will 'git status' say you're ahead or behind (or both) origin/master?
